body: @yzhliu can you review this?
@wjtan99 Supported values for USE_BLAS are `openblas`, `atlas`, `blas`, and `apple`.

I convert caffe model to mxnet model, I use mxnet as frontend, but I get a error:

FILE nnvm/python/nnvm/top/nn.py, in compute_conv2d.
assert dilation == (1, 1), "not support dilate now" .

Can I get some help ?
@Huyuwei
same problem #1005

Are you using a custom schedule for your model? Usually this is caused by a schedule not being able to handle a specific input shape e.g., the input shape causes too much local memory to be used or too many threads per blocked to be allocated.

Hi,

My code is exactly the same as [here](http://nnvm.tvmlang.org/tutorials/from_keras.html#compile-the-model-on-nnvm) with the only difference - the model is my own. Its input is `288x512x3` which, I suppose, not too much for the GTX 1070 with 8 Gb.

Ok, then the issue is likely due to an operator not handling one or more of the shapes in your model correctly. One way to verify this is to temporarily try out more common shapes, e.g., those in Resnet-18 such as (224x224x3) and see that works.
Ok, thanks for the tip, I'll try it

Thanks for the reference. @merrymercy
But I did not explicitly bind the axis. I just  compiled mxnet model into .so lib using nnvm, then loaded it and ran with tvm runtime. So I wonder how the tvm decides the threads and blocks number automatically.

The related code is [TOPI](https://github.com/merrymercy/tvm/tree/master/topi).
Take convolution for examples. Convolution layers in mxnet model will be converted to topi's operators, then tvm call their schedule functions in [topi/cuda](https://github.com/merrymercy/tvm/blob/master/topi/python/topi/cuda/conv2d_nchw.py). These schedule functions bind the thread explicitly. Currently the rules for binding is hard coded by topi writers.

@sgxu  You can compose dilated conv using topi.nn.dilate and topi.nn.conv2d

It won't be difficult, just not implemented now.
Try make clean, then make and install again.

If you want to access C code for which Cython does not provide a ready to use declaration, you must declare them yourself. For example, the above sin() function is defined as follows:
```
cdef extern from "math.h":
    double sin(double x)
```
https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/external.html#external-declarations


Syntax error with the semicolon ?
Great. Thanks a lot. @merrymercy
please upgrade your cython and try again. Seems the newest version of cython is less restrictive on this
close and tahnks @merrymercy for the answers
see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/964
This being said, the semicolon should be preferably fixed. Feel free to send a PR to fix this:)

but probably it more about `nnvm`. What do you think about it?.. Will it be correct to answer "no, common shape not really works"?..

It appears what I am looking for is the select expression.  This works as I expected the if statement to work.

Looking through the python code, the only place that I find if statements is in the ir_builder.  That alone is a fairly confusing concept because that appears to avoid the use of constructs like compute_op and does in fact write directly to buffers, at least in tests.  So working at the ir_builder level appears to produce imperative code.  In fact, in a lot of cases, it appears to me that working at the ir_builder level allows more freedom.  

Honestly I have a *lot* more questions to ask; is there an appropriate place to start asking them?  For instance, the rules for kernel combining; it appears throughout both tvm and nnvm that eltwise operations are combined into any other operation but outside of those there is limited kernel combining.

This is confusing because the error is complaining about `llvm` not being enabled, though `llvm` should not be a requirement for CUDA codegen (https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/docs/how_to/install.md).

Can you verify that the target is the CUDA GPU?
The built-in example fails before the `ctx = tvm.gpu(0)`...

Good catch, can you send a PR to fix this?

@tqchen 
Ok, let me to fix it.
@tqchen ok. I'll do it.

I tried to analysis the problem, and I find that, the feedGraph is constructed by scraping the map of tensors, and computeOp is keys to locate stages.

So my understand is that computeOp connect tensors and stages 

But in cache_write and cache_read, new computeOps are created, even thought we replace the old computeOps to new computeOps, but the computeOp in tensor->op is the old one

So these may cause the errors relate to this one?

Hi Tianqi,
Thanks a lot for your feedback. I have replaced those messy overloads by using tvm.generic.add, tvm.generic.mul etc. In addition, functors are used as you suggested.
Maybe it has things to do with python2 vs 3, we need to make code compatible to both

Hmm... If that is the case, then the legality of such tvm.Expr is inconsistently determined for python2/3. Note that it is the master's code that fails such unittest (i.e., without applying any Tensor operator overloading). It means master branch have such inconsistency. Would it be an issue?

Thank your for the explanations.
I updated the code by putting all logics in generic ops, and fixed the naming issues.
OK i looked into it and it seems to be a problem of error propagation in cython, should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1046
please fix the current code by removing duplicated num_workers
close due to in-activity, feel free to reopen. Currently, we have schedule-opt -> IR -> IR-optimizaiton -> codegen->TVM Runtime. You can make the cut at any of these level
The verilog backend is not currently being tested in CI so that error was actually a sync issue with updated API, should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1047

The current verilog backend provide two things:
- Hook to verilog simulator so it makes TVM easy to run (in simulation) a customized ASIC design
- A simple code generator that generates tvm dsl into verilog(generating hardware)

The first one is already fully functioning. The testcase has a basic version for second one. But second goal is not realized atm besides the simple demo testcase. Note that this is different from generate ISA that runs on ASIC which is what TVM's current major focus of the next release roadmap
close due to inactive status, feel free to reopen
close due to inactive status, we adopt an aggressive issue closing policy so all issues can be act upon.  feel free to reopen or followup with new issues

was traveling in last few days, this is great! Once you feel it is good to reach out to folks, maybe you could send a guest blogpost to tvmlang.org . I am less familiar with what clojure users care about but maybe you have better ideas of motivating examples
no idea, the javatest do pass in the CI though. could due to mismatch of ABI, try to build things from scratch maybe and use the same compiler for both tvm and jni compilation
ping @sxjscience can you take another look
ping @ZihengJiang

`cache_read` will return a new tensor that is a cached copy of the source (in this case data). So I believe you also need to specify where this cached copy will be produced (via `compute_at`). 
http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/optimize/opt_conv_cuda.html has some examples of how these primitives are used.
Thanks for your informative review. I did the corresponding updates.
closes #957
thanks to @ HungMingWu #1048

I have looked through the changed code but do not fully understand why it is the case(see comment), can you add a comment block on what the algorithm logic suppose to do?
The error for passing in cpu context is correct because we expect gpu. try the latest version in master and it might throw a error and tell you which graph causes the problem
cc @eqy @Laurawly
@tqchen can you please reopen this PR, i accidentally closed it.

Hi,

According to your suggestion, I rebuilt latest `nnvm` (`c8832cc1c57fc35d8f1e8042c258ac32c0309ebc`) with the latest `tvm` (`567a10bb0947180b067f39a97c76d7fe7a3ca1f2`) and traceback doesn't changed:
```
src/runtime/cuda/cuda_module.cc:93: CUDAError: cuModuleLoadData(&(module_[device_id]), data_.c_str()) failed with error: CUDA_ERROR_INVALID_PTX
```
for my own model and
```
src/codegen/codegen.cc:27: Check failed: bf != nullptr Target llvm is not enabled
```
for Keras ResNet-50 example.

Actually cache_read will equal the code as below,  maybe it can be used as a workaround.

import tvm
shape = (255,)
data_origin = tvm.placeholder(shape, name="data_o")
data = tvm.compute((shape), lambda i: data_origin[i], name="data")
#data = tvm.placeholder(shape)

a = tvm.compute(shape, lambda i: data[i] + data[i], name = "a")

b = tvm.compute(shape, lambda i: data[i] + a[i], name = "b")

c = tvm.compute(shape, lambda i: data[i] + b[i], name = "c")

res = tvm.compute(shape, lambda i: data[i] + c[i], name = "res")

s = tvm.create_schedule(res.op)

#s.cache_read(data, "local", [a, b, c, res])
s[data].set_scope("local")
print tvm.lower(s, [data_origin,  res], simple_mode = True)
Review comments are updated in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1051
@janboeye yes the procedure is same for one layer too.
If one wanted to help with the verilog code generation, where would be the best place for one to start?

I am also less familiar with clojure users than one might think.  I like it and am very productive with it so that is good enough for me.  TVM is a *great* counterpart to clojure regardless as the Venn diagrams of their respective strengths do not overlap. 


I sprinted to get the above to work; it is really more of a vision of what could be than a reality.  I only support injective kernels and I did the kernel combining manually as opposed to using the scheduling system to do it.  The TOPI library has a *lot* of very good complex pieces that I want to comb through and the other articles on the tvmlang.org page contain quite a lot of valuable information.
  

So, thanks, I will start working on what will probably be a series of blogposts because I am targeting at least 2 non-overlapping audiences; the core talent behind clojure and the core talent behind tvm.
Closing for now (might reopen if other issues surface later)

Ok, now I am getting
```
[arm64-v8a] Compile++      : tvm4j_runtime_packed <= ml_dmlc_tvm_native_c_api.cc                                                                                                                                 
In file included from tvm/apps/android_rpc/app/src/main/jni/ml_dmlc_tvm_native_c_api.cc:8:
In file included from tvm/apps/android_rpc/app/src/main/jni/tvm_runtime.h:24:
tvm/apps/android_rpc/app/src/main/jni/../../../../../../include/../src/runtime/threading_backend.cc:84:7: error: use of undeclared identifier 'pthread_setaffinity_np'; did you mean 'sched_setaffinity'?
```
I'm not sure if there needs to be more compile options enabled due to the use of pthreads, but just `-lpthreads` doesn't seem to work.
Check out the implementation of that file, seems was due to __ANDROID__ macro path not present
I mean the backend.cc

Right, looks like the macro is firing properly but there is no `__ANDROID__` version implemented.

Adding 
```
#if defined(__ANDROID__)
      sched_setaffinity(0,
        sizeof(cpu_set_t), &cpuset);
#else
```
seems to fix the build, but I have not tested the app yet.
OK, seems due to problem introduced by latest PR, can you send a patch?

cc @cowanmeg

What should be done about the schedule of elemwise div in `mean` after sum which is commReduce? The following error occurs:

`RuntimeError: Not yet support ewise after reduce`

Injective is also unsupported on CUDA, apparently. commReduce also doesn't work because there's no reduction axis.

I _guess_ I could do div-then-sum, but then I'd have to trust that Halide will reorder the operations.
